data.title: Peter Fretwell, Author at British Antarctic Survey
data.text:
Full list of published papers January 2015:

See also https://scholar.google.co.uk/citations?hl=en&user=5qOogLUAAAAJ

Ancel, A., R. Cristofari, et al. (2014). “Emperors in Hiding: When Ice-Breakers and Satellites Complement Each Other in Antarctic Exploration.” PloS one 9(6): e100404.

Atkinson, A., V. Siegel, et al. (2008). “Oceanic circumpolar habitats of Antarctic krill.” Mar Ecol Prog Ser 362(1): 23.

Barnes, D. K., M. A. Collins, et al. (2011). “The need to implement the Convention on Biological Diversity at the high latitude site, South Georgia.” Antarctic Science 23(04): 323-331.

Belchier, M. and P. Fretwell (2009). “Revised estimates of the aRea of the south GeoRGia and shaG Rocks shelf (ccamlR subaRea 48.3).” CCAMLR Science 16: 167-175.

Black, M., A. Fleming, et al. (2014). “On the Atmospheric Correction of Antarctic Airborne Hyperspectral Data.” Remote Sensing 6(5): 4498-4514.

Cooper, A. P. R. and P. Fretwell (2003). “A placename geography for Antarctica.” Bulletin of the Society of Cartographers 37(2): 53-55.

Dawson, A. G., S. Hampton, et al. (2002). “Defining the centre of glacio‐isostatic uplift of the last Scottish ice‐sheet: the Parallel Roads of Glen Roy, Scottish Highlands.” Journal of Quaternary Science 17(5‐6): 527-533.

Fretwell, P. (2012). “Modelling raised shorelines and patterns of Holocene isostatic rebound in the South Shetland Islands.” Quaternary International 279: 151-152.

Fretwell, P., I. Peterson, et al. (2004). “The use of Gaussian trend surfaces for modelling glacio-isostatic crustal rebound.” Scottish Journal of Geology 40(2): 175-179.

Fretwell, P., H. Pritchard, et al. (2012). “Bedmap2: improved ice bed, surface and thickness datasets for Antarctica.” The Cryosphere Discussions 6(5): 4305-4361.

Fretwell, P., H. D. Pritchard, et al. (2013). “Bedmap2: improved ice bed, surface and thickness datasets for Antarctica.” The Cryosphere 7(1): 375-393.

Fretwell, P., D. Smith, et al. (2008). “The last glacial maximum British–Irish ice sheet: a reconstruction using digital terrain mapping.” Journal of Quaternary Science 23(3): 241-248.

Fretwell, P., A. Tate, et al. (2009). “Compilation of a new bathymetric dataset of South Georgia.” Antarctic Science 21(02): 171-174.

Fretwell, P. T., P. Convey, et al. (2011). “Detecting and mapping vegetation distribution on the Antarctic Peninsula from remote sensing data.” Polar biology 34(2): 273-281.

Fretwell, P. T., D. Hodgson, et al. (2010). “Holocene isostatic uplift of the South Shetland Islands, Antarctic Peninsula, modelled from raised beaches.” Quaternary Science Reviews 29(15): 1880-1893.

Fretwell, P. T., M. A. LaRue, et al. (2012). “An emperor penguin population estimate: the first global, synoptic survey of a species from space.” PloS one 7(4): e33751.

Fretwell, P. T., I. J. Staniland, et al. (2014). “Whales from space: counting southern right whales by satellite.” PloS one 9(2): e88655.

Fretwell, P. T. and P. N. Trathan (2009). “Penguins from space: faecal stains reveal the location of emperor penguin colonies.” Global Ecology and Biogeography 18(5): 543-552.

Fretwell, P. T., P. N. Trathan, et al. (2014). “Emperor penguins breeding on iceshelves.” PloS one 9(1): e85285.

Graham, A. G., P. T. Fretwell, et al. (2008). “A new bathymetric compilation highlighting extensive paleo–ice sheet drainage on the continental shelf, South Georgia, sub‐Antarctica.” Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems 9(7).

Hoffman, J. I., A. Clarke, et al. (2012). “Unexpected fine-scale population structure in a broadcast-spawning Antarctic marine mollusc.” PloS one 7(3): e32415.

Hughes, K. A., P. Fretwell, et al. (2011). “Untouched Antarctica: mapping a finite and diminishing environmental resource.” Antarctic Science 23(06): 537-548.

LaRue, M. A., G. Kooyman, et al. (2014). “Emigration in emperor penguins: implications for interpretation of long‐term studies.” Ecography.

Martin, A., S. Poncet, et al. (2009). “The white-chinned petrel (Procellaria aequinoctialis) on South Georgia: population size, distribution and global significance.” Polar biology 32(4): 655-661.

Murphy, E., E. Hofmann, et al. (2013). “Comparison of the structure and function of Southern Ocean regional ecosystems: The Antarctic Peninsula and South Georgia.” Journal of Marine Systems 109: 22-42.

Smith, D., S. Shi, et al. (2005). “The Holocene Storegga Slide tsunami in the United Kingdom.” Quaternary Science Reviews 24(3): 2291-2322.

Smith, D., S. Shi, et al. (2004). “The holocene storegga slide tsunami in the United Kingdom.” Quaternary Science Reviews 23(23): 2291-2321.

Smith, D. E., P. T. Fretwell, et al. (2006). “Towards improved empirical isobase models of Holocene land uplift for mainland Scotland, UK.” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences 364(1841): 949-972.

Trathan, P. N., P. T. Fretwell, et al. (2011). “First recorded loss of an emperor penguin colony in the recent period of Antarctic regional warming: implications for other colonies.” PloS one 6(2): e14738.

Vaughan, D. G., D. K. Barnes, et al. (2011). “Potential seaways across West Antarctica.” Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems 12(10).

Wakefield, E. D., R. A. Phillips, et al. (2012). “Foraging black-browed albatrosses target waters overlaying moraine banks-a consequence of upward benthic-pelagic coupling?” Antarctic Science 24(03): 269-280.

Watcham, E., M. Bentley, et al. (2011). “A new Holocene relative sea level curve for the South Shetland Islands, Antarctica.” Quaternary Science Reviews 30(21): 3152-3170.
